Viewing Data in the Browser

Viewing Data in the Browser

  1. Youâ€™ve added a lot of books to your bookstore, but wouldnâ€™t it be nice to actually see them in the browser? You are building a web application after all.

  2. Before you can see your books, youâ€™ll need make some changes. Open the bookstore directory in your text editor.

  3. Now open config/routes.rb and add the following line inside the only block in the file:

    resources :books

  4. Save your changes.

  1. Go back to Terminal and make sure youâ€™re in the bookstore directory.

  2. Run rake routes. You should see a bunch of stuff about books along the lines ofâ€¦

       Prefix Verb   URI Pattern               Controller#Action
    books GET    /books(.:format)          books#index
          POST   /books(.:format)          books#create
 new_book GET    /books/new(.:format)      books#new
edit_book GET    /books/:id/edit(.:format) books#edit
     book GET    /books/:id(.:format)      books#show
          PATCH  /books/:id(.:format)      books#update
          PUT    /books/:id(.:format)      books#update
          DELETE /books/:id(.:format)      books#destroy

    rake routes prints a table of the available routes in your application. Since you added books as a resource in config/routes.rb, your application has a bunch of book routes.

    The URI Pattern column tells you how to reach the routes from a browser.

    For example, when your application is running locally you can reach /books by going to http://localhost:3000/books.

  1. Letâ€™s trying going to the /books route.

  2. In Terminal, run rails server to start your applicationâ€™s web server.

  3. Now, open your favorite web browser and go to http://localhost:3000/books.

  4. If I had to guess, you probably got an error :)

  1. Weâ€™ve run into a problem, but Rails is giving us some info to help us understand whatâ€™s going on.

    Youâ€™re getting a Routing Error because thereâ€™s an uninitialized constant BooksController. Rails is expecting your application will have a BooksController, so letâ€™s create it!

  2. Stop your rails server by running Ctrl-c.

  3. Create the BooksController by running touch app/controllers/books_controller.rb.

  4. Restart your web server by running rails server, and try going to http:://localhost:3000/books again.

    That still errored, didnâ€™t it? But hey, at least you got a new error!

  1. Now you got a LoadError because BooksController isnâ€™t defined.

    Unable to autoload constant BooksController, 
expected /Users/awesomesauce/Projects/bookstore/app/controllers/books_controller.rb 
to define it

  2. Remember the touch command we used to create the BooksController?

    touch app/controllers/books_controller.rb

    It created the BooksController file, but the file is empty. Donâ€™t belive me? Letâ€™s take a look.

  1. If youâ€™re text editor isnâ€™t already open, open it and go to the bookstore directory.

  2. Now, open app/controllers/books_controller.rb.

  3. See, itâ€™s empty :)

    touch creates empty files. We used it to create an empty file called app/controllers/books_controller.rb.

  4. The error you got said something about there being a missing constant BooksController. Letâ€™s add it.

  5. Add the following code to app/controllers/books_controller.rb:

    class BooksController < ApplicationController
end

    That should define the constant Rails was looking for.

  6. Save the file and try going to http://localhost:3000/books again.

    New error!

  1. This new error is telling us that youâ€™re BooksController doesnâ€™t have an index action. That kinda makes sense - we didnâ€™t add very much code to the BooksController. But why does it care that the index action is missing?

  2. Remember the routing table? Kinda? Donâ€™t worry, itâ€™s fuzzy for me too. Letâ€™s pull it up again.

  3. Go back to Terminal and stop the rails server by running Ctrl-c.

  4. Now, run rake routes. Voila - the routing table.

  5. The first entry in the routing table is for the /books path.

    Prefix Verb   URI Pattern       Controller#Action
 books GET    /books(.:format)  books#index

    The last column tells us which controller and action get run when we go to the /books path.

    The URI Pattern /books(.:format) maps to the Controller#Action pair of books#index. This tells us requests to the /books path will be routed to the BooksController index action.

    Clear as mud, right? Donâ€™t worry, itâ€™ll make more sense later.

  6. Now that we (kinda) know why weâ€™re trying to run the index action`, letâ€™s add it.

  7. Before we go on, restart your web server by running rails server.

  1. In your text editor, open the BooksController and add the following method inside the BooksController class.

    def index
end

  2. Save your changes and try going to http://localhost:3000/books again.

  1. Weâ€™re making progress. Seriously! The /books path is sucessfully reaching the BooksController index action, but weâ€™re getting an error because weâ€™re missing a template.

    A template is a view that getâ€™s rendered at the end of a controller action. In this case, Rails is expecting your applicaiton to have an index template to go with the BooksController index action.

    Letâ€™s make that happen!

  2. Stop your rails server by running Ctrl-c.

  3. All templates live in app/views.

    app/views will have directories for each of the controllers in your application. By default, a controllerâ€™s template directory will be the name of the controllerâ€¦minus the controller.

    For example, the BooksControllerâ€™s template directory will be app/views/books.

  4. Create the BooksController template directory by running mkdir app/views/books.

  5. Now, create the BooksControllerâ€™s index template by running touch app/views/books/index.html.erb.`

  6. Restart your web server.

    (Remember? Start your web server by running rails server.)

  7. Now, try going to http://localhost:3000/books.

    Yay, no errors!

  1. Ok, letâ€™s make this page a little more interesting.

  2. In your text editor, open app/views/books/index.html.erb and add the following line:

    <h1>Welcome to My Super Rad Bookstore!</h1>

  3. Save your changes and go to http://localhost:3000/books again.

    Yay! ðŸŽ‰

Youâ€™ve been going to the /books path a bunch and as a result youâ€™ve been running the BooksController index action a lot.

You can think of the index action as the index of a book because itâ€™s used to list all of a controllerâ€™s resources. Since weâ€™re in the BooksController, this index action is going to list all of the applicationâ€™s books.

  1. Before you can show all of your applicationâ€™s books, you have to make the books data available.

  2. In your text editor, open app/controllers/books_controller.rb. Inside the index method, add the following line:

    @books = Book.all

    That line might look a little familiar. We used Book.all in Chapter 2 to list all your applicationâ€™s books in the rails console. Weâ€™re using the same method again so we can render your applicationâ€™s books in the browser.

  3. Save your changes.

  1. By making that change to the index action, youâ€™ve made book data available to your index template.

    Letâ€™s see what you can do with it.

  2. In your text editor, open app/views/books/index.html.erb and add the following line to the end of the file:

    <%= @books[0].title %>

  3. Save your changes and try going to http://localhost:3000/books again.

  1. Your applicationâ€™s data might be a little different than mine, but youâ€™re probably seeing the title to MY favorite book. Yippie!

    (If your data is different, youâ€™re seeing the title of some other bookâ€¦sigh ðŸ˜‰)

  2. You had to do a couple of things to get that title to show up in your browser.

    First in the BooksController index method, you defined an instance variable @books and assigned it all the books in your application.

    Then in the associated index template (app/views/books/index.html.erb), you used some funny looking syntax to get the first book and show itâ€™s title.

    Letâ€™s focus on that funny looking syntax for a few minutes.

  1. In your text editor, open app/views/books/index.html.erb.

  2. Remember that line you added to the end of the file?

    <%= @books[0].title %>

    Change it so it looks like this:

    <%= @books[1].title %>

  3. Can you guess what this will change? Reload http:://localhost:3000/books to see what happens.

  1. Youâ€™re seeing a different book title, arenâ€™t you?

    You used @books[0] to get the first book, and you changed it to @books[1] to get the next book.

  2. I bet you could get all the books to render on the index templateâ€¦

    Spend some time and see if you can get all the book titles to render. If youâ€™ve been following along with the tutorial, you should have seven books in your application.

    If you know some HTML, try listing the titles in an unordered list.

    Donâ€™t know very much HTML? Donâ€™t worry about it - youâ€™ll get familiar with it reaaaal soon. Just focus on getting the titles to render.

  1. What did you come up with?

    One way may have been to list out each book like this:

    <%= @books[0].title %>
<%= @books[1].title %>
<%= @books[2].title %>
<%= @books[3].title %>
<%= @books[4].title %>
<%= @books[5].title %>
<%= @books[6].title %>

    That renders all the book titles, but they end up getting rendered on a single line.

  2. If you know some HTML, you may have thrown in a few brs to give the titles some space like this:

    <%= @books[0].title %>
<br>
<%= @books[1].title %>
<br>
<%= @books[2].title %>
<br>
<%= @books[3].title %>
<br>
<%= @books[4].title %>
<br>
<%= @books[5].title %>
<br>
<%= @books[6].title %>

  3. Better yet, you may have even used an unordered list:

    <ul>
  <li><%= @books[0].title %></li>
  <li><%= @books[1].title %></li>
  <li><%= @books[2].title %></li>
  <li><%= @books[3].title %></li>
  <li><%= @books[4].title %></li>
  <li><%= @books[5].title %></li>
  <li><%= @books[6].title %></li>
</ul>

  4. If you used an unordered list, great! If not, no worries - update your solution to use an unordered list.

  1. Yay! Book titles!

    But doesnâ€™t a lot of that code in your template look just a littleâ€¦repetitive?

    <li><%= @books[0].title %></li>
<li><%= @books[1].title %></li>
<li><%= @books[2].title %></li>
...

    There has to be a better way!?

    There is :)

  2. Remember when you defined @books in the BooksController index method?

    @books = Book.all

    You defined @books to be a collection of all the books in your applicationâ€™s database. For our purposes, we can treat this collection like a Ruby Array.

  3. You can get each item of a Ruby array by itâ€™s index, and the first item starts at index 0.

    Does that sound familiar? Itâ€™s what you used to render the book titles.

      <li><%= @books[0].title %></li>
  <li><%= @books[1].title %></li>
  ...

    This works well, but itâ€™s a very manual process. You have to individually access each book to render its title. It also depends on us knowing how many books there are in the database.

  4. In Ruby, we donâ€™t have to access each book individually like this. We can use Arrayâ€™s each method to help us out.

    Letâ€™s see what that would look like.

  1. Go back to your terminal and quit the rails server by running Ctrl-c.

  2. Now, start the rails console by runningâ€¦rails console.

  3. Run the following code:

    books = Books.all

    You now have a books variable thatâ€™s been assigned all the books in your applicationâ€™s database. books can be thought of as a Ruby Array.

    Sound familiar :)

  4. Now, try running the following:

    books.each { |book| puts book.title }

  5. What happened?

    You used the each method to iterate over each book and print its title.

  6. The curly braces ({}) after each are the start and end of a block. Weâ€™ve seen the other block notation before - it starts with a do and ends with an end.

    Try running the following:

    books.each do |book|
  puts book.title
end

    The syntax might be different, but itâ€™s the same result - each of the book titles are printed.

  7. At the beginning of the block, you have a couple of pipes surronding book

    books.each { |book| ... }

    This is called a block parameter. In this case, it lets you access each book so you can print its title.

  8. Before, we wouldâ€™ve manually gone through each book to print its title.

    puts books[0].title
puts books[1].title
...

    Now, each lets us do it in a lot less code.

    books.each { |book| puts book.title }

  9. Try playing with the each method to see what else you can print out. You should be able print things like the book ids, authors, and quantities.

  10. When youâ€™re done exploring, run exit to exit the rails console and restart the rails server.

  1. Letâ€™s put this knowledge to work.

  2. In you text editor, open app/views/books/index.html.erb.

  3. At the end of the file, add a new, empty unordered list. It should look like this:

      <ul>
  </ul>

  4. Inside the new unordered list, weâ€™ll want to iterate over all the books assigned to @books and render a list item for each book title.

    We can iterate over @books by using the each method.

  5. Weâ€™ve seen how to use the each method on the rails console, but how will you use it in your template?

    To run Ruby code in your template, you have to put it inside some funny looking brackets:

    <% ... %>

    Everything inside <% %> will get run in your template.

    Weâ€™ve seen something similar before. Remember how you got the book titles to render?

    <%= @books[0].title %>

    The syntax is slightly different. <%= %> runs Ruby code and renders the result in your template.

    <% %> on the other hand only runs Ruby code. It does not render the result of that code.

  6. With that in mind, add the following code inside your new unordered list:

    <% @books.each do |book| %>
<% end %>

    Go to http://localhost:3000/books again. Did anything change?

    Nothing changed! Youâ€™re running @books.each in your template, but since itâ€™s inside <% %> the result of that block isnâ€™t rendered.

  1. Now that you have your block setup, youâ€™re ready to render some book titles.

  2. Spend a few minutes and see if you can get each book title to render as a list item inside the block.

    Inside the block, each book is availble to you as book.

    When youâ€™re done, you should see two identical unordered lists on http://localhost:3000/books.

  1. Did you get it?! Your new unordered list should look something like this:

    <ul>
  <% @books.each do |book| %>
    <li><%= book.title %></li>
  <% end %>
</ul>

    Update your solution to match this solution.

  2. Compare your two unordered lists. They both end in the same result, but one required a little more effort.

    <ul>
  <li><%= @books[0].title %></li>
  <li><%= @books[1].title %></li>
  <li><%= @books[2].title %></li>
  <li><%= @books[3].title %></li>
  <li><%= @books[4].title %></li>
  <li><%= @books[5].title %></li>
  <li><%= @books[6].title %></li>
</ul>

<ul>
  <% @books.each do |book| %>
    <li><%= book.title %></li>
  <% end %>
</ul>

    We can take advantage of the ability to run Ruby code inside Rails templates to do things quickly.

  3. You donâ€™t need to show both unordered lists, so go ahead and remove the first one.

  1. Now that you have book titles rendering, letâ€™s try adding some information.

  2. Update the books unordered lists so it includes the book author next to each author like this:

    whyâ€™s (poignant) Guide to Ruby by why the lucky stiff

  1. What did you come up with? Compare your solution with people around you.

    Inside the @books.each block, you shouldâ€™ve edited the list item so it renders each bookâ€™s author next to its title.

    <li><%= book.title %> by <%= book.author %></li>

  2. Before you wrap up, make sure you have the book authors rendering next to the book titles.
